MOBILIZING PRIVATE EQUITY AND DEBT FUNDS FOR SME AND INFRASTRUCTURE FINANCE IN EMERGING MARKETS AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
Investment Funds Group Team 11-11-2015 Outline Part I: Global evolution of private equity and debt funds â€¢ Section 1: Overall evolution of PE funds â€¢ Section 2: Emergence of private debt funds â€¢ Section 3: Venture capital funds â€¢ Section 4: Infrastructure funds
Part II: Mobilizing PE and debt funds in emerging markets and developing countries (EMDEs) â€¢ Section 1: Developing ecosystem for PE/VC in EMDEs â€¢ Section 2: Developing the PPP framework in EMDEs â€¢ Section 3: The role of Strategic Investment Funds (SIFs)

13 Section 3: After reaching a peak in 2008, venture capital fund raising dropped significantly following the international financial crisis in 2009 and 2010. 28 Part II: Mobilizing PE and debt funds in EMDEs
Section 1: Developing the ecosystem for PE/VC in EMDEs
Three pillars: â€¢ Pillar 1: legal and regulatory framework for PE/VC operations â€¢ Pillar 2: legal and regulatory framework for investments by institutional investors in asset class â€¢ Pillar 3: business enabling environment
29 Pillar 1: legal and regulatory framework for PE/VC operations ï¶ Fund regulator and capacity ï¶ PE/VC fund and fund manager regulations â€¢ fund legal structure (incl compartments) â€¢ qualified assets â€¢ qualified investors â€¢ management company legal structure â€¢ qualification of persons who conduct the business of management company â€¢ disclosure of ultimate controllers of management company â€¢ disclosure and resolution of conflict of interest â€¢ delegation of core manager functions â€¢ own funds â€¢ asset valuation rules â€¢ content of fund prospectus â€¢ disclosure to investors â€¢ auditing â€¢ reporting â€¢ depositary rules â€¢ cooperation with supervisory agency â€¢ penalties
30  Pillar 1: legal and regulatory framework for PE/VC operations
ï¶ Tax treatment â€¢ tax residency for foreign investment funds â€¢ tax pass through for fund legal structures (capital gains tax, withholding tax) â€¢ double taxation agreements ï¶ Investor protection â€¢ protection of minority shareholder rights â€¢ protection for investors in funds ï¶ Interest in portfolio companies â€¢ restrictions on issue or transfer of shares ï¶ Buyouts â€¢ regulations on buyouts by public auction â€¢ regulations on buyouts of listed companies ï¶ Protection of intellectual property rights â€¢ legal and regulatory framework for patents and trademarks â€¢ international treaties â€¢ enforcement ï¶ Bankruptcy procedures/creditor rights/partner liability â€¢ legal and regulatory framework for bankruptcy â€¢ treatment of foreign and domestic creditors â€¢ partner liability â€¢ enforcement
31 Pillar 1: legal and regulatory framework for PE/VC operations ï¶ Exits â€¢ listing rules on main exchange â€¢ listing rules on SME exchange ï¶ Exchange controls â€¢ regulations on inward investments â€¢ regulations on outward transfers of profits and capital gains ï¶ Corporate governance requirements â€¢ corporate governance requirements for funds â€¢ corporate governance requirements for investee companies ï¶ Contract enforcement â€¢ contract enforcement through court system â€¢ contract dispute resolution framework ï¶ Perceived corruption â€¢ transparency international index â€¢ doing business index ï¶ Accounting â€¢ IFRS implementation
32 Pillar 2: Legal and regulatory framework for investments by institutional investors in asset class
ï¶ Laws/regulations for investments by pension funds in PE/VC asset class
â€¢ rules-based regime: limits on investment in asset class â€¢ risk-based regime: benchmark portfolio
ï¶ Laws/regulations for investments by insurance companies in PE/VC asset class
â€¢ rules-based regime: limits on investment in asset class â€¢ risk-based regime: roadmap to Solvency II/risk-based regulatory regime
33 Pillar 3: Business enabling environment
ï¶ Supply side â€¢ Business incubators â€¢ Business accelerators â€¢ Angel investors â€¢ Angel investor groups
ï¶ Demand side â€¢ Seed co-investment funds â€¢ Hybrid PE/VC funds
34 Section 2: Developing the PPP framework in EMDEs
ï¶ Legal framework â€¢ enable contract form encompassing multiple obligations (DBFOM: design-build-finance-operate-maintain) â€¢ enable DBFOM contract for both user-pay and government-pay models â€¢ enable tender model based on dialogue with prospective bidders ï¶ Selection, preparation and appraisal â€¢ guidelines to assess and select PPP projects at all levels of government â€¢ focus on affordability, commercial feasibility and value for money ï¶ Fiscal management â€¢ relevance for government-pay projects â€¢ valuation of contingent liabilities â€¢ public debt limits ï¶ Institutional framework and architecture â€¢ roles of procuring agency, promoter, treasury, general attorney â€¢ creation of specialized bodies
35 Section 2: Developing the PPP framework in EMDEs (contâ€™d)
ï¶ Key drivers for mobilization of institutional investors including infrastructure PE/debt funds
â€¢ Significant project pipeline â€¢ Successful track record including resolution of disputes â€¢ Strong process management framework â€¢ Clarity of legal framework (PPP legality, enforceability and procurement transparency) â€¢ Strong political commitment and support â€¢ Public acceptability â€¢ Fiscal sustainability
36  Section 3: The role of Strategic Investment Funds (SIFs)
â€¢ SIFs being created by increasing number of governments and regional economic communities to serve as anchor investors for international and domestic institutional investors in domestic projects â€¢ Sectors: SOE turnaround, infrastructure PPP projects, SMEs â€¢ Original inspiration: Singapore Temasek, Malaysisa Khazanah, South Africa Public Investment Corporation â€¢ More recent examples:
â€¢ EU: European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) â€¢ SÃ©nÃ©gal: Fonds Souverain dâ€™Investissement StratÃ©gique (FONSIS) â€¢ Chile: Strategic Investment Fund â€¢ Under preparation
â€¢ Indonesia, Congo, CÃ´te dâ€™Ivoire, Morocco
37 Section 3: The role of SIFs (contâ€™d)
ï¶ SIF Feasibility: key elements
ï± governance structure: â€¢ separation between ownership and management functions â€¢ fund board defining overall investment strategy â€¢ fund management company responsible for investment and exit decisions â€¢ funds/compartments targeting specific sectors/investor risk profile
ï± regulatory framework â€¢ funds regulated by capital market authority
ï± investment strategy â€¢ SIF to invest as GP in infrastructure fund â€¢ SIF to invest as LP in SME PE/VC funds managed by private manager and GP
38 Section 3: The role of SIFs (contâ€™d)
ï± human resource strategy â€¢ recruitment from private sector (investment banking, project finance, private equity/venture capital) through international private recruitment agency
ï± project selection criteria â€¢ double trigger: IRR/ERR
ï± fund manager remuneration â€¢ fund management fees, share of carry, hurdle rate
ï± preliminary market sounding â€¢ international and domestic institutional investors incl pension funds, insurance companies, sovereign wealth funds (SWFs), private equity and debt funds
39 Investment Funds Group Team
Sevara Atamuratova Shanthi Divakaran Honglin (Holly) Li Samuel Schneider Research Analyst Sr. Financial Sector Specialist Learning Analyst Consultant
Michel Noel Thelma Ayamel Havard Halland Patrick J. McGinnis Head Program Assistant Economist Consultant

doc.repnme: Mobilizing private equity and debt funds for SME and infrastructure finance in emerging markets and developing countries
doc.abstracts: This report is organized into four sections: overall evolution of PE funds; emergence of private debt funds; venture capital funds; and infrastructure funds.
